Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is one of the core protocols of the Internet Protocol (IP) suite. It provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between applications running on hosts communicating over an IP network. TCP is widely used for applications that require guaranteed delivery, such as web browsing, email, and file transfers.

Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX. tip Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts. For example, use JSX to create an interactive button: <button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button> Click me!

Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin. Here are a few tips you might find useful. Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory. Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml. The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as: 2019-05-30-welcome.md 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images: The blog supports tags as well! And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

documents.t: Microservices has become an increasing popular architecture choice in the half decade. This chapter help to look at the core ideas behind microservices, the prior architecture that brought us here and reasons why this is so widely adopted.

Microservices are independently releasable services that are modeled around a business domain. A service encapsulates functionality and makes it accessible to other services via network - you can construct more complex system on this building block Example one microservice represent inventory, another order processing and another shipping, but together they form a complete E-commerce system. Microservices are an architecture choice that is focused on giving you many options for solving problems you might face. On outside, microservices look like a black box and implements API's which can be used by other services or consumers. Internal implementation of microservices is hidden from outside world. The language it uses and database it uses is hidden from outside world. Important - This means microservice architecture avoid using shared database in most circumstances. Microservices embrace the concept of Information Hiding. It means that it hides as much as information within the service and only exposes little information to outside world via external interfaces. This allows you to change the internal implementation of microservice easily without affecting the outside world as the as the external interface remains the same. Changes in microservice should affect upstream microservices, enabling independent releasability of functionality or s service. Having clear, stable service boundaries that don't change when the internal implementation changes results in a system that have looser coupling and strong cohesion.
Core ideas that must be understood when you explore microservices are

Independent Deployability is the idea that when you make a change to a microservice, you can deploy that change without having to deploy any other microservices. On surface, this seems like a simple idea, but it has a lot of implications. Getting into a habit of deploying microservices independently will inherit bring a lot of discipline to your development process. To ensure independent deployability, you need to ensure that the microservices are loosely coupled and have well defined interfaces. Some implementation choice make this hard to achieve, such as using a shared database or tightly coupling the microservices. To achieve independent deployability, there are so many things to get right that in turn brings own benefit The desire for loosely coupled services with stable interfaces guides our thinking about how we find our microservice boundaries in the first place.

Techniques like domain driven design help you to structure your code to better represent the real-world domain that software operates in. With microservice we use same idea to define the service boundaries. By modeling around business domain, we can make it easier to roll out new functionality and to recombine microservices in different ways to deliver new functionality to end users. Rolling out new changes to more than one microservice is costly, it involves coordination with multiple services possibly multiple teams, you also need to manage the order in which it gets deployed. The above takes more time than deploying to a single microservice. so keep multi-service changes infrequent as possible A relatable example of three layered architecture that teams follow is split based on technology choice. This architecture works well when you have the changes in the frontend or backend alone (particular layer). But often experience shows the change is often related to business needs and it often spread across all three layers. But modelling the layer according to end to end slices of business functionality we ensure that our architecture is arranged to make changes to business functionality as efficient as possible. With microservices we have made a decision to have strong cohesion based on business functionality and not on technical functionality. Three layer architecture based on technology

One of the things that people starting with microservice is not understanding the important of separate database per microservice If a microservice wants to access data held by another microservice, it should ask the second microservices to get the data This enforces clear interface best pratice which giving full control on what information to hide and what information to share via external interface Having shared database is a worst mistake in microservice it will defeat the clear boundary isolation purpose & independent deployability This separate database per microservice pushes us to define well defined external contract with back compatible fashion By hiding the database per microservice we reduce coupling.

The size of the microservice should be kept as which it is easily understood. Don't focus too much of the size. As you are starting out think how many microservices you can manage. As you have more services the complexity will increase and new need to learn new skills to adopt this standard. Focus on strong cohesion based on business domain & have clear service boundaries remains a priority than worrying about the size.

Microservices buy you options. They have a cost and you need to decide whether the cost is worth the options you want to take up The microservice architecture gives flexibility in many axes - organizational, technical, scale, robustness We don't know what the future holds so adopting microservices will give the flexibility to theoretically solve the problems we face down the line (But again it has cost) Finding the balance between keeping your options open and bearing the architecture is an real art While you are increasing the flexibility with microservices, you are increasing the pain too. So take microservice pattern as incremental adoption By incrementally adopting you have the flexibility to stop if required

Music corp an e-commerce company sells CDs online, uses simple three layered architecture. We like to add a feature to expose favorite genre of music. It will cause change in all the layers, UI, Backend & Database. The changes need to be coordinated between all teams to deploy. This is fine, because traditionally this is how company operate, engineers are grouped based on core competency of technology skills But today this approach got changed we need to build products faster so a team structure of poly skilled engineer owning end to end helps. This forces us how we change our org structure the team. Most of the changes we make to the system is based on business functionality & when such changes happens it mostly happens across all layers In the earlier example the cohesion is made on the technology choice but when we think about our team structure as vertical slices instead of horizontal now the cohesion is made out of business domain In this scenario if a team called customer profile team owns the end to end aspect the feature to add favorite genre is much localized change within that team

Microservices are often considered as the alternative to monolithic architecture. Monolith - refers to a single unit of code that is deployed as a single unit. Three common types The Single-Process Monolith The Modular Monolith The Distributed Monolith

Most common example - Where all the code is deployed as a single process. All the code is packaged as a single process, this architecture is simple to understand and easy to deploy. This architecture makes sense for smaller organizations, however this architecture has potential to grow as organization grows (The modular monolith)

The modular monolith is a subset of single process deployment that is organized into separate modules. Each module can be worked separately but they are all deployed as a single unit. For many organizations this architecture fits well when the module boundaries are clear. It offers high degree of parallel work without challenges of distributed system. Shopify is a good example of modular monolith One of the challenges of a modular monolith is that database tends to not have that separation and thus leading to significant challenges when needed to pull apart the monolith as microservices in the future. There are examples where org take this idea further and have a modular monolith with separate databases for each module.

The distributed monolith is a monolith that has multiple services but for whatever reason they are deployed as a single unit. It has the all disadvantages of a monolith and the all disadvantages of a distributed system without the benefits of either. This architecture is often the result of a poorly designed microservice or emerged in a environment in which not enough focus is placed on the concepts like information hiding, strong cohesion and loose coupling.

As more and more people working in the same place, they get in each other's way For example, different developers want to change same piece of code The boundaries of the ownership is not clear and this leads to contention Its doesn't mean that you will face this problem in monolith and also it doesn't mean you wont face this problem in microservices. Microservices architecture gives more better boundaries around which ownership can be defined and thus reducing the contention.

Advantages of monolith - Simple deployment topology can avoid many pitfalls with distributed services. Simple developer workflow, troubleshooting and E2E test are simplified. Code reuse is easier in monolith, in distributed system you need to decide whether to copy the code or share the code as library or pull as different microservice A monolith architecture isn't something bad, its an architecture choice that is appropriate for many organizations. Have justification for microservices, if you are not facing the problem of monolith then don't go for microservices.
Constantly look for issues caused by microservice distributed system and then adopt technology

With increasing number of services, it can be hard to understand how the system is working in production setting making troubleshooting difficult. Strongly recommend to use log aggregation and distributed tracing to understand how the system is working. Log aggregation is the process of collecting logs from multiple services and storing them in a central location. Enhance log aggregation tools even more powerful by implementing correlation IDs Correlation IDs are unique identifiers that are passed between services to help track the flow of a request through the system. Some tools humio, jaeger, light step and honeycomb are some of the tools that can be used for log aggregation & tracing

Run microservices in isolation to ensure one doesn't affect the other. Containerization is a technology that allows you to run applications in isolated environments. Virtualization is a technology that allows you to run multiple operating systems on a single machine. Both provides isolation but container is lightweight and faster to start than virtualization. Containers makes much sense for microservices as they are lightweight and can be started and stopped quickly. Kubernetes is a container orchestration tool that allows you to manage containers at scale. Don't use kubernetes for small scale applications, use when you have multiple services and need to manage them at scale. Use public cloud providers like AWS, GCP, Azure to manage the kubernetes cluster for you. Setting up kubernetes cluster is not easy and requires a lot of expertise & time.
Organization is moving towards more real time systems & products that allows to process data in real time are becoming more popular. Apache Kafka is a popular streaming platform popular.

Welcome to the Tech Books documentation! This space is dedicated to providing notes & insights into various software engineering books. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced developer, you'll find valuable resources to enhance your knowledge and skills.

Summaries of popular software engineering books. Key takeaways and actionable insights. Recommendations for further reading. Dive in and explore the world of software engineering through curated book content!

Microservices are an approach to distributed systems that promote the use of finely grained services that can be changed, deployed, and released independently. For organizations moving towards a more loosely coupled systems, with autonomous teams delivering user-facing functionality, microservices work incredibly well. Apart from this microservices gives us a huge number of options for building out systems, giving us a lot of flexiblity to ensure our system can change to meet the needs of the users. Microservices aren't without downsides. As a distributed system, they bring a host of complexity. Three parts in the book
What are Microservices? How to Model Microservices Splitting the Monolith Microservice Communication Style
Implementing Microservice Communication Workflow Build Deployment Testing From Monitoring to Observability Security Resiliency Scaling
User Interfaces Organizational Structures The Evolutionary Architect
Let's discover Docusaurus in less than 5 minutes.
Get started by creating a new site. Or try Docusaurus immediately with docusaurus.new.
Node.js version 18.0 or above: When installing Node.js, you are recommended to check all checkboxes related to dependencies.

Generate a new Docusaurus site using the classic template. The classic template will automatically be added to your project after you run the command: npm init docusaurus@latest my-website classic You can type this command into Command Prompt, Powershell, Terminal, or any other integrated terminal of your code editor. The command also installs all necessary dependencies you need to run Docusaurus.

Run the development server: cd my-website npm run start The cd command changes the directory you're working with. In order to work with your newly created Docusaurus site, you'll need to navigate the terminal there. The npm run start command builds your website locally and serves it through a development server, ready for you to view at http://localhost:3000/. Open docs/intro.md (this page) and edit some lines: the site reloads automatically and displays your changes.

The 7 Behaviors That Separate Juniors from Seniors As a senior engineer having technical skills alone is not important. Being good at the functional skills is important but is required not sufficient What should be shown is the How you go about the Job, the behaviors you exhibit are the things that signal to others that you are operating at next level

Junior engineers identity the problems & escalate the problem upward to more authority person. Senior engineers take the ownership, they identify, analyze & come with solutions. They are not looking for someone to solve the problem. They own & get others buy-in "The client expressed concerns about our timeline and budget. I've prepared three alternatives that address their concerns while protecting our other projects in-flight. Here's a quick analysis of each option, and my recommendation. I'd like your input before I respond to them."

Junior engineers answers when a question is asked Senior engineers proactively communicate the progress, obstecles & timelines before anyone about to ask This proactive communication isn't just about looking good‚Äìit's about reducing management overhead. Every time a manager has to ask for a status update, it's another thing on their already full plate. When team members push important updates without prompting, they're demonstrating leadership and lightening their manager's load. "I've completed the first three milestones on the checkout feature. We're on track for Friday's deadline, but I've identified a potential integration issue with the payment gateway that might cause a delay. I've already reached out to the payments team, and we've scheduled time tomorrow to resolve it"

Junior engineers focus on their own growth. Senior engineers recognize that their impact multiplies when they help others improve. One of the most telling signs of seniority is the shift from "How can I become better?" to "How can I make my team better?" This doesn't mean neglecting your own growth‚Äìit means recognizing that elevating those around you creates compound returns. "The best code I'll ever write is the code I help others write." "I created a guide to our data architecture with examples of common queries and pitfalls to avoid. I'm hosting a working session to walk through it and have already helped three team members implement it for their projects."

Junior behavior: "This project will take about two weeks to complete." Senior behavior: "I understand this project could increase customer satisfaction by 15%, which our data shows would lead to a 5% boost in retention. Given that potential impact, I recommend we prioritize it over the other items on our roadmap, which would have less direct impact on our key metrics." Juniors think in terms of tasks and timelines. Senior professionals connect their work to business outcomes. Understanding the "why" behind decisions allows seniors to make better trade-offs, prioritize effectively, and advocate for resources. It also positions them as strategic partners rather than just task rabbits

Junior behavior: "The requirements aren't clear. I won't start until they're finalized." Senior behavior: "The requirements have some ambiguity. I've identified the areas we can move forward on immediately, and I've scheduled time with stakeholders to clarify the uncertain aspects while development begins." Junior developers are often paralyzed by unclear requirements. Senior developers recognize that perfect clarity is rare and know how to make effective progress despite ambiguity. I've seen junior developers spend days, weeks, or even months waiting for "final" requirements that never come, while their senior counterparts were already building, testing assumptions, and iterating based on feedback. we often had to make decisions with incomplete information. My go-to approach was to break things down into "known" and "unknown" components, then start work on the known aspects while actively investigating the unknowns. If the unknown bucket was too big, sure, we needed to block waiting until there was more information, but most of the time there was a healthy set of things we knew needed to do.

Junior behavior: "When will my manager give me bigger scoped work?" Senior behavior: "I've identified an area on my own where I can add significant value beyond my current responsibilities. Here's my plan for taking this on while ensuring my primary work doesn't suffer." Juniors wait for growth opportunities to be handed to them. Seniors create their own opportunities by identifying gaps and stepping into them. Many engineers who felt stuck in their roles, waiting for someone to notice their potential and offer them more responsibility, but the most successful ones were those who proactively identified important work. The reality is that every workplace has way more problems than anybody could ever solve. Juniors only do the work that is assigned to them. Seniors search for and solve next-level problems that already exist

Junior behavior: "We need to completely refactor our codebase before adding any new features. It's a total mess, and I want to make everything clean and elegant first." Senior behavior: "I've identified the critical areas of technical debt in our codebase that are actively slowing us down. I've created a roadmap that lets us address these issues incrementally while continuing to deliver business value. We'll improve the most problematic components first and gradually enhance the architecture over time." Juniors often pursue the ideal at the expense of delivering value. They see perfection as a prerequisite to progress. Seniors understand that perfect code is impossible in evolving systems and have evolved a sense of ‚Äúgood enough,‚Äù which is still high-quality, but avoids expending effort on diminishing returns.
A structured system to handle stress, build self-worth, and grow consistently with confidence. Designed to help you become self-reliant person you aspire

üåÖ Morning ‚Äì Mind-Body Alignment (20‚Äì30 mins) ‚úÖ 5 min ‚Äì Breathwork (Box breathing or Anulom Vilom pranayama) ‚úÖ 5 min ‚Äì Write intention: ‚ÄúToday I want to feel _‚Äù; ‚ÄúTop 1 win = _‚Äù ‚úÖ 10‚Äì20 min ‚Äì Light workout or walk to activate energy

‚úÖ Choose ONE small goal (POC, reading, debugging) ‚úÖ After completion: log in ‚ÄúProof of Confidence‚Äù(What did I do? - What worked? - How did I feel?) ‚úÖ Use the ‚ÄúGrowth Map‚Äù to identify next micro-step
documents.s: Work Blocks ‚Äì Chunk, Focus, Build Proof

documents.t: ‚úÖ Ask: ‚ÄúWhat am I feeling right now?‚Äù ‚úÖ Label it: ‚ÄúThis is ___ (e.g., stress, doubt)‚Äù ‚úÖ Reframe: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs one truth I can hold onto?‚Äù ‚úÖ Optional: Walk/stretch, meditate, or listen to calming music

‚úÖ What did I learn today? ‚úÖ What challenged me? ‚úÖ What helped me feel better? ‚úÖ Log 1 win in ‚ÄúProof of Confidence‚Äù ‚úÖ Review growth map: update if needed ‚úÖ Optional: Gratitude or light meditation

üß≠ Weekly Deep Alignment Check-in üîç Self-awareness Did I grow this week? Did I overthink or spiral? What triggered it? üìà Growth Progress What skill did I improve? What‚Äôs next on my learning map? üß† Self-worth Rebuilding Which proof of confidence mattered most this week? What did I handle better than before? üåø Simplify & Realign What pressure am I holding unnecessarily? Anything to drop or adjust next week?

üìä Personal Retrospective üìò Review Proof of Confidence log ‚úÖ What themes are emerging? (e.g., overcoming doubt, completing POCs) ‚úÖ Where am I becoming more capable? üß† Growth Map Checkpoint ‚úÖ Which topics did I complete mastery on? ‚úÖ Where do I need deeper work? ‚úÖ What new topics or skills do I want to explore? üìÖ Goal Planning ‚úÖ What‚Äôs 1 project or milestone I want to finish next month? ‚úÖ What‚Äôs my learning focus? ‚úÖ What habit do I want to reinforce?

üìì Daily Journal / Notion Intentions, reflections, and confidence logs üó∫Ô∏è Growth Map Table: ‚ÄúI know ‚Üí I‚Äôll learn next ‚Üí Review on‚Äù ‚úÖ Weekly Tracker Checklist or template for alignment questions üìÇ Confidence Log Folder or note where daily wins are stored üìÜ Calendar Reminders Weekly & Monthly check-in nudges

Name the fear: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôll fail and it‚Äôll mean I‚Äôm not good enough.‚Äù Challenge the equation: ‚ÄúFailure ‚â† unworthy. It‚Äôs just part of building skill.‚Äù Recall proof: ‚ÄúI bounced back before. I learned new things, I shipped projects to millions of users.I‚Äôm learning fast.‚Äù
"Success for me is showing up daily, learning intentionally, and recording every small win. I don‚Äôt need to be perfect. I need to keep growing."

Burnout If you feel overwhelmed or burned out, take a step back. Focus on rest and recovery first. Use the following steps: Acknowledge: Recognize you‚Äôre feeling burned out. The feeling of burnout never goes away, but you can learn to manage it.

Keeping up with the pace of change in tech, especially in AI is overwhelming The high pace of tech learn can lead to burnout The pressure to constantly learn and adapt can be exhausting The work culture also a reason for burnout

Recognize that you are burned out See what all the things you are doing when you are not burned out How do you perform when you are calm See what your morning routine & evening routine when not burned out See your ideal baseline When you are burned out, the normal routine is missed Happens one day its fine, but when it happens for a week or two,it becomes a problem Do a weekly check-in or monthly check-in Recognize how excited you are up to work Is it boring, stressful or overwhelming Isolated in the case of burnout

Take a break: Step away from work and tech for a few days. But it comes when you join back Prioritize self-care daily: Focus on sleep, nutrition, and exercise(mental, physical). Follow your daily routine: Stick to your morning and evening routines to maintain structure. Building in rewards for yourself: See what energizes you and do it, don't always rely on external validation. Learn to say no: Avoid taking on too many commitments. Seek support: Talk to friends, family, or a mentor about how you‚Äôre feeling. Other people also feel the same feelings. It will help to collobarate and overcome burnout
A practical guide to help you negotiate effectively when buying a car in India ‚Äî from understanding taxes to timing your purchase and verifying the vehicle‚Äôs details.

The total GST on cars in India usually ranges from 35% to 45%, depending on the vehicle category and engine capacity. After GST, there‚Äôs often a 5% tax cut or government incentive, which can reduce the total cost by ‚Çπ1‚Äì2 lakh depending on the model. Tip: Before finalizing, always confirm if any manufacturer or state-level tax relief is applicable to your car.

Car showrooms typically earn only 1‚Äì5% profit margin from the car sale itself. They make most of their profits through add-ons such as: Insurance Accessories Extended warranties Hence, dealers often inflate insurance premiums. Instead: Compare and buy through Policybazaar, Coverfox, or directly from insurers. You‚Äôll get better coverage at lower cost, and it‚Äôs easy to digitally link with your purchase.
documents.s: üí° 2. Avoid Buying Insurance from the Car Dealership

documents.t: December is the best time to buy a car in India. Dealers offer big discounts to clear old inventory and hit annual sales targets. Typical offers include: Discounts on ex-showroom price Free accessories or extended warranties Exchange or loyalty bonuses üß† Pro Tip: Start negotiations in late November and finalize in December to get the maximum benefit.

Always ask for the VIN (Vehicle Identification Number) before booking or taking delivery. The VIN indicates the month and year of manufacture ‚Äî not just the registration date. Verify it using: The VAHAN app/portal Or the manufacturer‚Äôs VIN decoder Why this matters: Dealers sometimes sell older-manufactured vehicles (previous year‚Äôs stock). If the VIN shows an older year, demand extra discounts ‚Äî typically ‚Çπ50,000 to ‚Çπ1 lakh.
documents.s: üîç 4. Verify the Manufacturing Year Using the VIN

documents.t: Step Action Why It Matters 1 Check GST & tax cut benefits Save ‚Çπ1‚Äì2 lakh instantly 2 Buy insurance independently Avoid inflated dealer premiums 3 Purchase in December Get maximum offers & discounts 4 Verify VIN in VAHAN Ensure you get the latest manufactured model

Stay polite but data-driven ‚Äî back your argument with facts, not emotion. Ask for detailed breakup (Ex-showroom, RTO, insurance, add-ons). Negotiate total on-road price, not individual components. Be ready to walk away ‚Äî most dealers call back with a better offer. üß≠ Use these principles to save money, avoid hidden costs, and get the best value for your new car.
Motivation determines action. Low motivation leads to high procrastination.
‚Üë Motivation ‚Üí ‚Üì Procrastination
Motivation = (Belief (B) √ó Importance (I)) / (Distraction (D) √ó Delay (D))
Motivation on Demand Short-term Motivation ‚Äì Triggered by deadlines Long-term Motivation ‚Äì No clear deadline, harder to sustain

[ Panic Monster ] ‚Üí [ Instant Gratification Monkey ] ‚Üí [ Rational Decision Maker (CEO) ] The Monkey distracts you from important work. The Panic Monster appears close to deadlines, forcing urgent action. The CEO (Rational Decision Maker) takes charge when the Monkey is subdued or the Panic Monster kicks in.
documents.s: üêí The Mind's Internal Players (Tim Urban Model)

documents.t: ‚ÄúDo you believe you can do it?‚Äù Low belief = Low motivation How to increase belief: Set S.M.A.R.T. goals (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) Break tasks into manageable, achievable parts Reinforce small successes to shift belief upwards Belief is critical ‚Äî the foundation for sustaining motivation

‚ÄúHow important is the task?‚Äù Greater importance ‚Üí More motivation Boost importance by: Associating the pain of not completing the task Associating the pleasure and reward of completing the task Align tasks with bigger goals or personal values

‚ÄúHow often do you get distracted?‚Äù Frequent distractions lower motivation How to reduce distractions: Audit and track how often you get distracted Build the right systems (e.g., focus apps, distraction blockers) Improve your environment (declutter, noise-canceling, boundaries) Map distractions ‚Üí Identify patterns ‚Üí Remove or mitigate them

‚ÄúHow far away is the reward or consequence?‚Äù Longer delay reduces motivation Our brains are wired for instant gratification How to reduce delay impact: Shorten the feedback loop: Celebrate small wins Track progress visually (checklists, progress bars) Break long-term goals into smaller milestones with immediate rewards
Motivation = (Belief √ó Importance) / (Distraction √ó Delay) To increase motivation, work on: Increasing Belief and Importance Reducing Distraction and Delay

In projects or life, there are often recurring tasks that need to be managed effectively. Here‚Äôs a framework that can help you handle these tasks efficiently: Identify Recurring Tasks: List out all tasks that you find yourself doing repeatedly. This could include daily, weekly, or monthly tasks. Prioritize Tasks: Determine which tasks are most important or time-sensitive. This will help you focus on what needs to be done first. Create a Schedule: Develop a schedule that outlines when each task should be completed. The best you can use is calendar invites on a weekly & monthly basis. Automate Where Possible: Look for ways to automate tasks using tools or software. This could include setting reminders, using task management apps, or automating emails. Review and Adjust: Regularly review your task list and schedule. Adjust as necessary based on changes in priorities or new tasks that arise. Delegate: If possible, delegate tasks to others to free up your time for more important activities. Reflect and Improve: After completing tasks, take a moment to reflect on what worked well and what could be improved. Use this feedback to refine your approach for the future.
Use this guide before making any type of purchase ‚Äî small or large, essential or optional. It‚Äôs designed to help you make intentional, value-driven decisions.
Does this save time or eat time? It automates or speeds up my work/life. It will create maintenance, distraction, or effort over time. Buy if: it saves more time than it costs.

Does this put money in my pocket eventually? It‚Äôs an investment (tools, skills, leverage). It helps reduce future spending. It‚Äôs just a cost without return. Buy if: it earns money or avoids future expenses.

Am I genuinely happy making this purchase? It brings lasting satisfaction (not just a quick dopamine hit). It aligns with my values, goals, or identity. It‚Äôs not driven by boredom, stress, or FOMO. Buy if: it still feels good after reflection.

Have I compared prices and options? Searched on Amazon, Flipkart, Meesho, eBay, etc. Used ChatGPT to compare product quality, prices, and reviews. Looked for discounts, cashback, or bundle deals. Buy if: it‚Äôs the best value for money.
Have I waited before buying this? Waited 24‚Äì72 hours before purchasing. Still want it just as much after the waiting period. Buy if: desire remains after a cooling-off period.
Assign a 1‚Äì5 score for each criterion below: Criteria Score (1‚Äì5) Time Impact Financial Value Emotional Check Price Comparison Cool-Off Period Total Score
21‚Äì25: Buy with full confidence ‚úÖ 16‚Äì20: Reconsider or delay ‚è≥ Less than 16: Likely not worth it ‚ùå ‚ÄúEvery purchase is a trade ‚Äî of time, energy, or attention. Spend wisely.‚Äù
Can money buy happiness? Can spending money make you happier?

People constantly chase one financial goal after another ‚Äî ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be happy when I earn X.‚Äù Every time one goal is achieved, the next appears ‚Äî a shifting goalpost that keeps happiness out of reach. Real happiness begins with contentment and gratitude for what we already have. Money can amplify happiness ‚Äî but only if you are already happy.
Family and friendships Purposeful & meaningful work Good physical and mental health Strong intimate relationships A positive environment and community
Money enhances, not replaces, these sources of happiness. If happiness keeps moving with your goals, you‚Äôll never catch it. Learn to value what you have before chasing what‚Äôs next.

People who use money as a tool ‚Äî to gain freedom, experiences, and time ‚Äî lead happier lives. Those who chase money for status or validation often feel empty. Buying luxurious things to prove worth or impress others leads to temporary satisfaction. What they truly seek is attention, appreciation, and respect ‚Äî things that money can‚Äôt buy. True respect can be earned through character, kindness, and relationships, not possessions.
documents.s: Using Money as a Tool vs. Being Controlled by It

documents.t: Use money as a tool to support your values, not as a scoreboard to prove your worth.
Every person‚Äôs financial behavior makes sense when you understand their past, their experiences, and their context.

Spending Reflects the Past‚Äã How people spend money often mirrors what they lacked or experienced in childhood or early life. Money habits are emotional echoes of personal history. Everyone Has Unique Variables‚Äã Each person‚Äôs background, culture, and struggles are different. What seems irrational from the outside often makes perfect sense within their life context. Judgment vs. Understanding‚Äã We shouldn‚Äôt judge others‚Äô financial choices without knowing their story. Money behavior is deeply personal ‚Äî not universally ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad.‚Äù Universal Cautions‚Äã Some financial patterns are harmful for everyone ‚Äî greed, debt addiction, or exploitation. Compassionate help makes sense when these occur.

Morgan Housel quotes Warren Buffett: ‚ÄúWhen you get to my age, you will realize that the measure of your success in life is how many people you want to have love you, actually do love you.‚Äù Love and respect are the ultimate currencies ‚Äî money can‚Äôt buy them. Genuine affection must be earned through who you are, not what you own.

I realize that dreams ‚Äî owning a luxury home or a BMW/Benz ‚Äî often stem from wanting admiration and respect. But genuine love and respect can be earned through being a good parent, spouse, and friend. Success isn‚Äôt about possessions but about how people feel about you.

Observe what truly makes you happy ‚Äî then maximize it: Spending quality time with family Helping or teaching others Having deep conversations with friends Playing Legos with your kid Show off the inside of your house, not the outside. Let your kindness, character, and values be visible ‚Äî not your wealth. Contentment is built by cherishing what you already have. Your worth is not tied to money, but to how much genuine love and respect you attract. Wealth without love feels empty. Love without wealth still feels full.
All behaviors make sense with enough information. Understand people before judging them ‚Äî and measure your success by how many people genuinely love and respect you.

Happiness doesn‚Äôt scale with money ‚Äî it scales with gratitude, purpose, and connection. Money is a tool, not an identity. Empathy over judgment ‚Äî everyone‚Äôs financial story is different. True wealth = peace of mind + meaningful work + good relationships + self-respect. Real success = being loved by the people you love.
Happiness isn‚Äôt something you find after achieving your goals ‚Äî it‚Äôs something you nurture while you‚Äôre pursuing them.

The Illusion of Future Contentment‚Äã We often imagine that future success ‚Äî a bigger home, luxury car, or higher salary ‚Äî will bring lasting happiness. The Moving Target of Desire‚Äã Once a goal is achieved, the mind jumps to the next one, creating a cycle of endless pursuit. The Happiness Gap‚Äã Happiness = What you have today ‚Äì What you expect The gap between expectation and reality defines dissatisfaction. Shrinking this gap by lowering expectations or appreciating what you already have creates instant contentment. A healthy gap motivates progress; an ever-widening gap leads to perpetual chasing of money and things. The Practice of Appreciation‚Äã True happiness comes from: Noticing and valuing what you already have Celebrating achievements and progress Cultivating daily gratitude Happiness is an active habit, not a distant goal.

I often fall into the ‚Äúfuture contentment trap,‚Äù thinking happiness comes after reaching X. By observing the happiness gap, I see I can feel content today by appreciating what I already have. Lowering unnecessary expectations doesn‚Äôt stop ambition ‚Äî it allows me to enjoy the journey while still growing.

Stop postponing happiness for future achievements. Take deliberate pauses to reflect and celebrate progress. Build a habit of daily gratitude ‚Äî it rewires your mindset for contentment. Enjoy the journey, not just the destination. Happiness is cultivated, not purchased.
The happiest people you know aren‚Äôt chasing endlessly ‚Äî they appreciate what they have today while wisely pursuing tomorrow.
Happiness depends on much more than income. Money alone doesn‚Äôt guarantee fulfillment ‚Äî it‚Äôs what it enables indirectly that matters.

The Limits of Wealth‚Äã Many of the richest people lack happiness in personal life. Example: Among the 10 richest men in the world, 13 divorces occurred. Thought experiment: $100,000/year + loving spouse, admired children, supportive friends, good health ‚Üí meaningful life $1 billion + none of the above ‚Üí empty life Lesson: Form (wealth) without substance (relationships, health, purpose) is hollow. The Indirect Benefits of Spending‚Äã Spending on things often increases happiness not because of the item itself, but because of what it enables: Hosting friends and family in your home Sharing experiences together Creating moments of connection and joy The real source of happiness is relationships and shared experiences ‚Äî money is just a facilitator. Invisible Effects‚Äã Money‚Äôs true value comes from what you don‚Äôt see: Emotional security Time for loved ones Ability to give and create shared experiences Focusing only on visible wealth (houses, cars, gadgets) misses the deeper returns that actually produce happiness. Real-Life Example: Mark Randolph (Co-founder of Netflix)‚Äã Randolph says: ‚ÄúI resolved a long time ago not to be one of those entrepreneurs on the 7th startup and the 7th wave. In fact, the thing I‚Äôm most proud of in my life is not the companies I started, it‚Äôs that I was able to start them while staying married to the same woman, having my kids grow up to like me, and being able to spend time pursuing other passions. This is my definition of success.‚Äù Lesson: Real success = balancing achievements with relationships and personal well-being.

This reinforces that happiness and success are about relationships, balance, and meaningful experiences, not just financial milestones or status symbols. Money is a tool to enhance connections, not a substitute for them.

Don‚Äôt measure happiness solely by income or possessions. Focus on relationships, health, purpose, and experiences. Use money to enable connection and shared joy, not to signal status. Recognize the invisible benefits of wealth ‚Äî they matter far more than visible ones. Life balance and love are as important, if not more, than any business achievement.
Happiness and success aren‚Äôt in wealth alone ‚Äî they‚Äôre in the invisible parts of life: love, relationships, and meaningful experiences.

Happiness and financial freedom come from not needing to impress others. When we stop seeking validation through material possessions and focus on nurturing our inner values, we find true contentment.

The Trap of Impressing Others‚Äã Many people spend money on external things ‚Äî luxury cars, big houses, expensive gadgets ‚Äî to gain admiration and validation from others. This creates a cycle of unhappiness: The satisfaction from impressing others is temporary. The constant need to maintain appearances leads to stress and dissatisfaction. The Freedom of Letting Go‚Äã The most valuable financial asset is the ability to stop caring about impressing others. When you stop seeking external validation, you free yourself from unnecessary financial and emotional burdens. Nurturing Inner Happiness‚Äã True happiness comes from focusing on what you genuinely love and value, not what others think. Inner fulfillment is built by: Pursuing passions and meaningful work Spending time with loved ones Cultivating gratitude and self-respect The Paradox of Impressing‚Äã People who try the hardest to impress others often feel the least secure. Those who are content with themselves don‚Äôt feel the need to prove their worth through possessions.

I‚Äôve realized that the desire to impress others often leads to unnecessary spending and stress. By focusing on what truly matters to me ‚Äî family, meaningful work, and personal growth ‚Äî I can find happiness without external validation.

Stop spending money to impress others ‚Äî it‚Äôs a never-ending cycle. Focus on what brings you genuine joy and fulfillment. Build self-worth from within, not from external possessions. True wealth is the freedom to live authentically, without worrying about others‚Äô opinions.
The most valuable financial asset is the freedom to stop impressing others. Happiness comes from nurturing your inner values and focusing on what truly matters to you.

Happiness and financial freedom come from not needing to impress others. When we stop seeking validation through material possessions and focus on nurturing our inner values, we find true contentment. The Joy of Giving: A Real-Life Example‚Äã Chuck Feeney, the co-founder of Duty-Free Stores, donated 99.99% of his $8 billion fortune before he passed away. Feeney found joy in giving his money to others and helping them, rather than owning luxurious apartments or cars. He initially tried the path of luxury but realized it didn‚Äôt bring him happiness. Helping others and making a difference gave him true fulfillment. Personal Reflection: This resonates deeply with me. It reinforces the idea that happiness comes from giving and creating impact, not from accumulating wealth or possessions.

I‚Äôve realized that the desire to impress others often leads to unnecessary spending and stress. By focusing on what truly matters to me ‚Äî family, meaningful work, and personal growth ‚Äî I can find happiness without external validation. The story of Chuck Feeney inspires me to think about how I can use my resources to help others and create a positive impact.

Stop spending money to impress others ‚Äî it‚Äôs a never-ending cycle. Focus on what brings you genuine joy and fulfillment. Build self-worth from within, not from external possessions. True wealth is the freedom to live authentically, without worrying about others‚Äô opinions. Giving and helping others can bring deeper happiness than accumulating possessions.

The most valuable financial asset is the freedom to stop impressing others. Happiness comes from nurturing your inner values, focusing on what truly matters to you, and finding joy in giving and helping others.
Article on performance tuning : Postgres Performance Tuning

Postgres performance tuning involves optimizing the database configuration, queries, and hardware resources to ensure efficient and fast operations. Key areas to focus on include: Configuration Tuning: Adjust parameters like shared_buffers, work_mem, and maintenance_work_mem to optimize memory usage. Tune max_connections and effective_cache_size based on workload and available resources. Indexing: Use appropriate indexes (e.g., B-Tree, GIN, GiST) to speed up query performance. Regularly analyze and vacuum indexes to maintain their efficiency. Query Optimization: Use EXPLAIN and EXPLAIN ANALYZE to understand query execution plans. Avoid unnecessary joins and subqueries; use proper filtering and aggregation. Vacuum and Analyze: Regularly run VACUUM and ANALYZE to update statistics and reclaim storage space. Enable autovacuum for automatic maintenance. Connection Pooling: Use tools like PgBouncer or Pgpool-II to manage database connections efficiently. Hardware Optimization: Ensure sufficient CPU, memory, and disk I/O capacity. Use SSDs for faster read/write operations. Monitoring and Logging: Monitor performance metrics using tools like pg_stat_activity and pg_stat_statements. Enable logging for slow queries to identify bottlenecks. By implementing these strategies, you can significantly improve the performance and scalability of your PostgreSQL database.

Use Branch Protection Rules: Enforce rules on branches to ensure code quality and prevent unauthorized changes. This includes requiring pull requests for changes, enforcing status checks, and restricting who can push to the branch. Code Owners & PR Templates: Use CODEOWNERS files to define who is responsible for code in specific directories. This helps in ensuring that the right people review changes. Also, use pull request templates to guide contributors on how to submit changes. Remove unused branches: Regularly clean up branches that are no longer needed. This helps in keeping the repository organized and reduces clutter. Use the git branch -d <branch-name> command to delete local branches, and git push origin --delete <branch-name> to delete remote branches.

Changing the remote Git repository URL in a local Git repository can be done using the git remote set-url command. This is useful when you want to switch from one remote repository to another, such as changing from a personal repository to an organizational one. git remote set-url origin https://sathish-thangavel@github.com/<org>/<repo>.git
If you want to set the local Git username and email for the repository, you can use the following commands: git config user.name "<Your Name>" git config user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set local git username and email

documents.t: If you want to set the global Git username and email, which will apply to all repositories on your machine, you can use the following commands: git config --global user.name "<Your Name>" git config --global user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set global git username and email

documents.t: To verify that the remote URL has been changed, you can use the following command git remote -v

You have just learned the basics of Docusaurus and made some changes to the initial template. Docusaurus has much more to offer! Have 5 more minutes? Take a look at versioning and i18n. Anything unclear or buggy in this tutorial? Please report it!

Read the official documentation Modify your site configuration with docusaurus.config.js Add navbar and footer items with themeConfig Add a custom Design and Layout Add a search bar Find inspirations in the Docusaurus showcase Get involved in the Docusaurus Community

Delete all GitHub Actions workflow runs from a repository using PowerShell and the GitHub CLI. While GitHub‚Äôs retention settings only clear the logs inside workflows, they don‚Äôt remove the workflow entries themselves. To solve this, we can write a PowerShell script as highlighted in the below blog Source Blog : Delete all github workflow runs using powershell Create a powershell script named run.ps1 param ( [string]$Owner, [string]$Repo ) if (-not (Get-Command gh -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue)) { Write-Host "GitHub CLI (gh) is not installed. Please install it from https://cli.github.com/" -ForegroundColor Red exit 1 } if (-not $Owner -or -not $Repo) { Write-Host "Usage: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>" -ForegroundColor Yellow exit 1 } $workflowRuns = gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs --paginate --jq '.workflow_runs[].id' foreach ($runId in $workflowRuns) { Write-Host "Deleting workflow run ID: $runId" gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId -X DELETE } Write-Host "All workflow runs have been deleted." This script does a few things: Accepts the owner and the repository as arguments. Run it as: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>. Avoids hard-coding values so it can run across different repositories easily. Checks if the GitHub CLI (gh) is installed by calling Get-Command on gh. Validates that both the owner and repository name are provided. Retrieves all workflow runs by calling the repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs endpoint with --paginate to fetch all pages of results. For each workflow run ID, sends a DELETE request to repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId to remove the run. Before running the script, make sure you‚Äôre authenticated with your GitHub account: gh auth login Once you logged in, call the script with a repo to which you have access and where you want to erase all workflow runs. Example command: .\run.ps1 -Owner glibnub -Repo waittimes-aggregator All the workflow runs will be deleted after this command

Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is one of the core protocols of the Internet Protocol (IP) suite. It provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between applications running on hosts communicating over an IP network. TCP is widely used for applications that require guaranteed delivery, such as web browsing, email, and file transfers.
How to Increase Network TCP/IP Connections in Linux 1,000,000 Concurrent TCP Connections EC2 Tuning for +1M TCP Connections using Linux Redhat TCP Window Scaling
Documents are groups of pages connected through: a sidebar previous/next navigation versioning
Create a Markdown file at docs/hello.md: docs/hello.md # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! A new document is now available at http://localhost:3000/docs/hello.

Docusaurus automatically creates a sidebar from the docs folder. Add metadata to customize the sidebar label and position: docs/hello.md --- sidebar_label: 'Hi!' sidebar_position: 3 --- # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! It is also possible to create your sidebar explicitly in sidebars.js: sidebars.js export default { tutorialSidebar: [ 'intro', 'hello', { type: 'category', label: 'Tutorial', items: ['tutorial-basics/create-a-document'], }, ], };
Docusaurus creates a page for each blog post, but also a blog index page, a tag system, an RSS feed...

Create a file at blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md: blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md --- slug: greetings title: Greetings! authors: - name: Joel Marcey title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1 url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey image_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey.png - name: S√©bastien Lorber title: Docusaurus maintainer url: https://sebastienlorber.com image_url: https://github.com/slorber.png tags: [greetings] --- Congratulations, you have made your first post! Feel free to play around and edit this post as much as you like. A new blog post is now available at http://localhost:3000/blog/greetings.
Add Markdown or React files to src/pages to create a standalone page: src/pages/index.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/ src/pages/foo.md ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo src/pages/foo/bar.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo/bar

Create a file at src/pages/my-react-page.js: src/pages/my-react-page.js import React from 'react'; import Layout from '@theme/Layout'; export default function MyReactPage() { return (

My React page

This is a React page

 ); } A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-react-page.
Create a file at src/pages/my-markdown-page.md: src/pages/my-markdown-page.md # My Markdown page This is a Markdown page A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-markdown-page.
Docusaurus is a static-site-generator (also called Jamstack). It builds your site as simple static HTML, JavaScript and CSS files.
Build your site for production: npm run build The static files are generated in the build folder.

Test your production build locally: npm run serve The build folder is now served at http://localhost:3000/. You can now deploy the build folder almost anywhere easily, for free or very small cost (read the Deployment Guide).
Docusaurus can manage multiple versions of your docs.

Release a version 1.0 of your project: npm run docusaurus docs:version 1.0 The docs folder is copied into versioned_docs/version-1.0 and versions.json is created. Your docs now have 2 versions: 1.0 at http://localhost:3000/docs/ for the version 1.0 docs current at http://localhost:3000/docs/next/ for the upcoming, unreleased docs

To navigate seamlessly across versions, add a version dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'docsVersionDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The docs version dropdown appears in your navbar:

It is possible to edit versioned docs in their respective folder: versioned_docs/version-1.0/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/hello docs/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/next/hello
Let's translate docs/intro.md to French.
Modify docusaurus.config.js to add support for the fr locale: docusaurus.config.js export default { i18n: { defaultLocale: 'en', locales: ['en', 'fr'], }, };

Copy the docs/intro.md file to the i18n/fr folder: mkdir -p i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/ cp docs/intro.md i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md Translate i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md in French.

Start your site on the French locale: npm run start -- --locale fr Your localized site is accessible at http://localhost:3000/fr/ and the Getting Started page is translated. caution In development, you can only use one locale at a time.

To navigate seamlessly across languages, add a locale dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'localeDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The locale dropdown now appears in your navbar:
Build your site for a specific locale: npm run build -- --locale fr Or build your site to include all the locales at once: npm run build
Docusaurus supports Markdown and a few additional features.

Markdown documents have metadata at the top called Front Matter: my-doc.md --- id: my-doc-id title: My document title description: My document description slug: /my-custom-url --- ## Markdown heading Markdown text with [links](./hello.md)

Regular Markdown links are supported, using url paths or relative file paths. Let's see how to [Create a page](/create-a-page). Let's see how to [Create a page](./create-a-page.md). Result: Let's see how to Create a page.

Regular Markdown images are supported. You can use absolute paths to reference images in the static directory (static/img/docusaurus.png): ![Docusaurus logo](/img/docusaurus.png) You can reference images relative to the current file as well. This is particularly useful to colocate images close to the Markdown files using them: ![Docusaurus logo](./img/docusaurus.png)

Markdown code blocks are supported with Syntax highlighting. ```jsx title="src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js" function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; } ``` src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; }

Docusaurus has a special syntax to create admonitions and callouts: :::tip[My tip] Use this awesome feature option ::: :::danger[Take care] This action is dangerous ::: My tip Use this awesome feature option Take care This action is dangerous

MDX can make your documentation more interactive and allows using any React components inside Markdown: export const Highlight = ({children, color}) => ( { alert(`You clicked the color ${color} with label ${children}`) }}> {children} ); This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue ! This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue !
